1.57.text:
- [Voiceover] Funding
 for Election 2014
 coverage is provided

3.77.text:
in part by AARP, a non-profit,
 non-partisan association,

8.74.text:
86,000 strong in North Dakota,
 AARP fights on real issues

13.95.text:
that matter to you
   and your family.

16.25.text:
And by the members
   of Prairie Public.

35.34.text:
- Welcome to Prairie
  Public's continuing coverage

37.20.text:
of Election 2014, I'm Matt
   Olien, this is the debate

42.91.text:
My guests today are
  Democrat Ryan Taylor

46.91.text:
and Republican Agriculture
  Commissioner Doug Goehring.

51.08.text:
Based on a coin flip to
   determine order of opening

53.22.text:
and closing statement,
   Ryan Taylor will go first

55.79.text:
with a one minute
   opening statement.

58.12.text:
- Thank you, Matt,
   thanks to Prairie Public,

60.06.text:
and thanks to AARP
  for sponsoring this.

62.46.text:
Ag Commissioner is an
 important race in North Dakota

64.73.text:
this year, mainly because
   agriculture is our

67.40.text:
number one industry,
 but the decisions made

69.77.text:
by Ag Commissioner deal
with both agriculture

71.54.text:
and energy and how
 we balance those two.

73.87.text:
After 125 years of statehood
  with agriculture pulling

77.71.text:
the cart, we need to
make sure that as we go

79.81.text:
through energy development
  that agriculture's not lost.

82.92.text:
I have to thank my wife
   Nikki, my wife of 11 years

86.05.text:
who's been through five
elections with me since the day

89.22.text:
we got married at Keene First
 Lutheran in McKenzie County,

93.86.text: on the campaign trail with me.

96.13.text:
Nikki and I went through three
 very successful campaigns

98.70.text:
for the State Senate where I
  learned the ropes of policy

102.27.text:
making in North Dakota, served
 on the Agriculture Committee.

105.97.text:
I studied Agriculture at
   NDSU right here in Fargo.

109.64.text:
So as we go into this
  race, we realize that those

111.95.text:
are skills that we
 need to bring forward,

114.25.text:
knowledge of agriculture,
fourth generation on our family

117.38.text:
cattle ranch with hopefully
  my sons or daughter--

119.79.text:
- [Matt] Okay, that's one
   minute. - [Ryan] Being
   the fifth generation.

121.25.text: - That's one minute, we need to

122.69.text:
stick you to the one
  minute on openings.

124.32.text:
Doug Goehring, one
   minute opening statement.

127.23.text:
- Doug Goehring, I am North
Dakota Agriculture Commissioner.

130.26.text:
I'm a third generation
   farmer, I farm with my son

133.23.text:
near Menoken in south
 central North Dakota.

136.87.text:
Agriculture is one of
 our leading industries
 in North Dakota

139.37.text:
and I'm proud of the fact
  that in the last four years

141.37.text:
we've increased exports by
about 40-- by about 70 percent.

146.91.text:
Also, I'm committed to those
  initiatives that best serve

150.22.text:
North Dakota and North
 Dakota agriculture,

151.92.text:
which is diversity, innovation,
research, and trade.

156.76.text:
We have a great story to
 tell, and part of it goes back

160.76.text:
to the whole fact that we
  are the envy of the nation.

165.80.text:
the fastest growing economy,
  80 percent of North Dakotans

168.33.text:
feel we're headed in
  the right direction,

171.20.text:
and we've even been
 characterized as being

173.81.text:
the happiest state in the
   nation, edging out Hawaii.

177.58.text:
I will continue to be and
  committed to being balanced

182.02.text:
and a common sense approach
  towards regulations.

186.22.text:
It's important that we continue
to protect our farmers--

188.76.text:
- [Matt] Okay, that's
 one minute, Doug. -
 [Doug] And ranchers.

190.29.text:
- One minute, okay, let's
  move on to our first topic.

191.99.text:
You can come back
   to those things

193.23.text:
in the closing
statements if you want.

195.43.text:
Doug Goehring, you're going
 to start first on this topic.

197.96.text:
Let's start with the
 Ag Commissioner's role

199.70.text:
in the Industrial
Commission, how do you,

201.97.text:
if either one of you
  are elected, balance
  the oil interest

204.50.text:
versus the energy interest
versus the agricultural interest

207.71.text:
and how do you each feel about
 the special places proposal

210.01.text:
as well, Doug Goehring,
you start now.

213.01.text:
- My role in the Industrial
  Commission goes back

216.15.text:
to the whole issue
 surrounding representing those

219.42.text:
that have an interest on the
  land here in North Dakota.

222.42.text:
Agriculture is vitally
 important, it's our number one

224.16.text:
industry in North Dakota,
  and we need to be out there

226.99.text:
protecting and helping
  those farmers and ranchers.

229.56.text:
And that goes back to my plan
 and my stance on mitigating

232.83.text:
risk, minimizing impact,
and shrinking that

235.74.text:
footprint on the prairie, and
 understanding that there is

239.31.text:
a constitutional
 right to develop those
 minerals and trying

242.21.text:
to work on that and balance
 that approach and making sure

245.28.text:
that those farmers and
   ranchers have the ability

248.31.text:
to call and use our program,
  our mediation program,

252.72.text: to address some of those issues.

254.35.text:
Four years ago we
 took the approach of
 broadening the scope.

257.99.text:
I went to the legislature
  to broaden the scope of that

260.36.text:
program to help those farmers
 and ranchers so that we

263.63.text:
can minimize those
  impacts on the land.

265.93.text:
And when we have issues, we
  need to go back and address

269.10.text:
those with companies, and
  that's what I've been doing.

273.71.text:
- The Industrial Commission
  is a primary role for the

276.94.text:
Commissioner of Agriculture,
  that's why I brought out

278.58.text:
a landowner's bill of
  rights early in the campaign

281.15.text:
because I know that the
   landowners, those farmers

283.05.text:
and ranchers who produce
a crop above the ground

285.35.text:
need to have their
   interests balanced

286.85.text:
with those mineral
 developers who have the right

288.76.text:
to pull the resources out
   from below the ground.

291.39.text:
These are simple things
that I would propose

294.33.text:
that allow us to do
both, still get the oil,

297.43.text:
but still have a
  crop on top so that

300.00.text:
they're protected
 from salt water spills

301.67.text:
so that those landowners
know that there's going

303.30.text:
to be reclamation when the
 oil is gone so the topsoil is

305.61.text:
back in place for them to farm
 and to ranch that same land.

308.74.text:
To make sure that their kids'
 bedroom window has got enough

310.98.text:
space between that drilling rig
and their house so that they

314.28.text:
can go to bed at night
 if there's a flare
 burning out there.

317.72.text:
I would always look out for
  the interest of agriculture

320.79.text:
on the Industrial Commission
to make sure that this industry

323.72.text:
that has brought us to the
   dance is well represented.

326.79.text:
We will have to do both,
   and we know that sometimes

330.30.text:
existing industries like
 agriculture can feel the brunt

333.27.text:
of development in not
always the best of ways.

336.14.text:
So we need to bring
  people together.

337.60.text:
We need to bring agriculture
  and energy together.

339.57.text:
Energy could play for 30, 40
 years or more in North Dakota.

343.18.text:
But agriculture
  will always be here.

345.01.text:
It is the definition
of a renewable industry

347.81.text:
and renewable resources,
  ever since our homesteading

350.42.text:
grandparents came here, so I
 would take that responsibility

353.69.text:
extremely serious to make
 sure that farmers and ranchers

359.09.text:
- Doug Goehring, you want
  to hop back in and respond?

361.63.text:
- The other issue about
  special places, that was one

364.60.text:
of the things that I stood and
 firmly opposed, simply based

368.27.text:
on the fact that if you are
 going to identify a few places

373.61.text:
in North Dakota as
  being significant or
  special, what does

377.01.text:
that mean for the rest of
 those places in North Dakota?

379.35.text:
Our farmers and ranchers
  suffer quite often scrutiny

384.35.text:
from the public and from
 activists about their farming

387.02.text:
and ranching habits
  out on the prairie.

389.72.text:
And this was no different,
   all they did was

391.39.text:
turn their attention
  towards energy at the time.

394.19.text:
They will turn it
  back to agriculture.

395.93.text:
And I wanted to make
sure that we weren't put

397.86.text:
in the position
 whereby identifying
 a few special places,

401.43.text:
which have been characterized
 by some, that all of a sudden

405.04.text:
agriculture would get picked
 on at a later date where cows

407.57.text:
and combines would no longer
  be... have that opportunity

411.61.text:
to be out on the prairie
in somebody's viewshed.

414.61.text:
Those are my concerns, we've
  seen it in the western part

417.28.text:
of the United States, especially
where we have federal lands

420.79.text:
and some states lands out
   in the western Rockies.

424.12.text:
And it's a concern, we
can't go down that road.

426.63.text:
We shouldn't open that
door, we do need to take

429.83.text:
the same approach on every
   piece of land out there.

433.17.text:
And that again goes back
   to mitigating those risks,

436.07.text:
minimizing those impacts,
  and shrinking that footprint

439.07.text:
so that we have the
 least amount of impact

441.07.text:
for our farmers and ranchers
  and the least amount

443.94.text:
of effect on them
   and their lives.

446.18.text:
- Okay, Ryan Taylor,
  last word on this,

447.58.text:
and then we'll
   move to farm bill.

449.28.text:
- Good to touch
   on special places.

450.78.text:
When the Republican Attorney
  General Wayne Stenehjen

453.19.text:
brought up the special places
 proposal, I looked at it

455.19.text:
very hard because I wanted
   to know the impacts of it.

459.83.text:
I think it was a modest
 proposal that looked at saving

462.66.text:
what North Dakotans would
   define North Dakota as

464.83.text:
for generations to come, still
 allow energy to get the oil

468.50.text:
from beneath that ground,
  did not preclude development

472.21.text: in my reading of that proposal.

474.21.text:
And I think that North Dakotans
by and large would like

476.91.text:
to save some of those
 places so that we can

481.61.text:
I believe the energy
  industry would still be able

483.58.text:
to pull the oil out
from under that ground.

485.62.text:
And, obviously, we need
to protect agriculture

488.02.text:
in this entire mix, and to say
 that, you know, it would be

491.69.text:
a slippery slope would be
 abdicating our responsibility.

494.66.text:
My responsibility would
  make sure that the proposal

497.36.text:
was specific and that it
   didn't include agriculture

500.63.text:
and that the ranchers would
 always get to graze their cows

503.17.text:
on that ground, and that
   we would continue to hold

505.67.text:
the culture that's brought
   North Dakota through this

507.71.text:
125 years, bringing the
  people together to make sure

510.71.text:
we can do both the energy
   and Ag, as we've advocated

514.71.text:
all along in this process
   and save something

519.92.text:
- Okay, let's move to farm
bill, what is each of your views

522.32.text:
on the recently enacted farm
  bill and what would you like

524.39.text:
to see changed or enacted
   in the next farm bill?

526.86.text:
Ryan Taylor, you
start this time.

528.79.text:
- Farm bill is critically
   important in North Dakota.

531.16.text:
And I think it's a primary
  role of our Ag Commissioner,

533.63.text:
although it's federal policy
  to advocate on behalf of

536.20.text:
North Dakota farmers who
   depend on that farm bill.

539.44.text:
Obviously, this was
 a long-fought battle.

542.07.text:
I think we could have
been more vocal from the

544.64.text:
Ag Commissioner's office
  early and often to make sure

547.71.text:
that there weren't political
  games being played in it.

550.72.text:
I think what came through
   has been generally pretty

553.72.text:
well accepted by farmers and
  ranchers, provisions of it.

557.66.text:
The devil will be in
   getting those details down

560.13.text:
as the rules are set, but
  we wanted to come through it

563.60.text:
with a strong crop
  insurance provision.

566.37.text:
I know that my neighbors and
  friends who farm and ranch

568.70.text:
across North Dakota
   depend on that completely

571.47.text:
as a safety net, and
   it's the one that we need

574.17.text:
to keep and maintain
  in North Dakota.

576.74.text:
There's obviously some
livestock provisions that helped

579.51.text:
those who had a
  disastrous blizzard

581.71.text:
in the southwestern
corner of North Dakota.

584.35.text:
We often hear of it
 most in South Dakota.

587.49.text:
That was something that
needed to come early

589.52.text:
for our ranchers that
 needed that help.

592.73.text:
And I would make sure that
 those in Washington understand

595.76.text:
the impact of it so that we
 don't play games of splitting

598.80.text:
this title from that title,
  to make sure that we have

601.43.text:
something that's going
 to be very successful

603.20.text:
in the political process that
 really affects our economy.

607.91.text:
- My concern is now that
   we have this new farm bill

611.11.text:
and how we got here, certainly
 bothers me a great deal

617.98.text:
This is a non-traditional
   farm bill.

620.39.text:
It is completely stripped
   off from all the support

622.69.text:
that it had in previous years
 over many, many decades.

626.83.text:
And what we were hoping to
 get out of it was even a more

629.56.text:
enhanced crop insurance
   component for agriculture.

633.73.text:
It has some different
 components to it.

635.70.text:
Some of it has been enhanced,
 but for the most part

638.14.text:
we stripped away a lot of
   support for agriculture,

641.24.text:
production of agriculture
   in the United States.

643.71.text:
Two things came out of it, the
 price loss coverage concept

648.38.text:
and the agriculture
 risk coverage concept.

652.52.text:
Both of those are important,
  price loss coverage concept

656.29.text:
actually fits the south
 better than it does the north.

659.46.text:
The rest of the midwest, it
  will probably be agriculture

662.13.text:
risk coverage that will
 cover us, the majority of our

665.40.text:
producers here in North
   Dakota and in the midwest.

669.20.text:
The other bothersome thing
   about it was the fact that

674.87.text:
coming into that
   entire farm bill.

677.68.text:
That really tied the
 hands of our producers

680.01.text:
in the upper midwest,
 and especially

681.71.text:
those in North Dakota,
that's of great concern.

685.48.text:
We do have something a
 little bit better now,

687.69.text:
but it still has some
 complexities to it.

689.49.text:
We're going to have to figure
 it out as we move forward.

691.46.text:
I know we're getting closer
  to those signup dates.

693.59.text:
There's a lot of anxiety
about what plan somebody

696.03.text:
should take, what
   they should do,

697.46.text:
because the other thing
 about this, once you sign up,

699.70.text:
you're locked into that,
there's no changing.

708.34.text:
are vitally important
 to our producers.

710.11.text:
We're doing a little bit
  more all the time for animal

714.48.text:
But unfortunately, we stripped
 away a lot of support really

717.65.text:
for production agriculture
 when we look at grain farming.

720.82.text:
And unfortunately, we tied
   conservation compliance

724.32.text:
back into it and that is
damaging to our farmers.

729.50.text:
- I think we both agree on the
 importance of the farm bill

732.43.text:
and knowing that it's always
  going to get a little bit

734.33.text:
tougher to pass that farm
   bill in Washington, D.C.

737.97.text:
And I know that as Ag
 Commissioner, we need someone

740.41.text:
who can communicate
across both party lines

743.44.text:
and across urban and
   rural divides to make sure

746.31.text:
that all of our country
realizes the importance

748.91.text:
of a strong food policy,
  whether you're representing

751.85.text:
an urban district in New
 York City or a rural district

754.92.text: in the great plains of America.

757.79.text:
I think we'll go forward
  and learn from this process

760.76.text:
knowing that our farm
 organizations who
 I would listen to

765.16.text:
as Ag Commissioner, are going
 to have in-depth knowledge

769.17.text:
of these issues, how they
   affect them on the ground,

772.30.text:
know that livestock is an
important sector in this state.

775.51.text:
And we realize this year,
   I think, how important

777.94.text:
the provisions are as crop
 prices plummet, as we struggle

782.08.text:
to get grain on the rail
and get it to market.

785.35.text:
And while the cattle market
  is very good right now,

787.89.text:
we know that those things
   change in a heartbeat.

791.99.text:
- Okay, Doug Goehring,
 I'll give you

793.16.text:
the last word and
  then we'll move on.

795.19.text:
- A couple of years ago
in August I asked all

797.66.text:
the Ag community in North
   Dakota to come together

800.43.text:
to sit down and talk about
   what it is that we can all

802.50.text:
agree upon, what we'd like
   to see in a farm bill.

805.47.text:
And when they got there, the
  one thing that we threw out

808.61.text:
and talked about right away
  is I said, I understand

810.91.text:
where everybody has
 a standing policy at,

813.38.text:
and I understand where
 your sacred cow is.

815.85.text:
But you're going to have
to take that sacred cow

817.75.text:
to Washington and
   sacrifice it on that altar

820.72.text:
because right here in North
  Dakota we need to talk about

823.32.text:
what is good for
everybody in this state.

826.16.text:
And we did work
   on crop insurance.

827.89.text:
Unfortunately, we had issues
  with the Washington Post

830.60.text:
and the New York Times that
  misrepresented the amount of

833.50.text:
support that was really
   being received by farmers

837.47.text:
from the federal government,
  and when they did that,

840.37.text:
it did us a great disservice
  because we weren't able

842.47.text:
to get over some of those
   humps and get to Congress

845.38.text:
on the issues about
supporting our industry

848.71.text:
with a better crop
   insurance program.

852.48.text:
We're looking at some
   other supportive materials

855.29.text:
and products that can
 probably be used in this next

858.79.text:
farm bill, but it's going
   to take some more work.

861.96.text:
- Let's move on to another
issue that's within the purview

864.10.text:
of the Industrial
 Commission, and that's

865.53.text:
the Bank of North Dakota,
   Mr. Taylor, you recently

867.67.text:
came out with some
student loan proposals.

871.40.text:
How do we balance student
 loan proposals, easing burdens

875.27.text:
on students, and how
  do you guys manage

876.98.text:
that Bank of North
 Dakota and that debt,

880.25.text:
Doug Goehring, you
  go first this time.

881.75.text:
- Well, first of all,
we were very responsible

885.75.text:
about four or five months
  ago when we finally took on

889.42.text:
this issue and decided what
  it was we were going to do

894.43.text:
We looked at the DEAL
 Consolidation Loan,

897.00.text:
and we took interest rates on
 a fixed down to 5.29 percent.

902.10.text:
We then looked at
 the variable rates on

905.84.text:
a DEAL Consolidation Loan,
   took them down to 1.73.

909.68.text:
And if you took automatic
   payment, 1.48 percent.

913.05.text:
Our problem isn't just
 continuing to lower

915.61.text:
that interest rate, it really
 has to do with making sure

919.72.text:
that we can lower the
 cost of education.

922.79.text:
That's an issue that we
  need to continue to take up

925.59.text:
with the legislature, but
   part of that goes back

928.49.text:
to stimulating and supporting
 a robust economy to generate

931.70.text:
the revenue so that we can
   use that revenue to offset

935.47.text:
the higher cost of education
because it's just like farming.

938.74.text:
You could give farmers
 interest-free money.

941.67.text:
They still have the
  debt to pay back.

943.54.text: We need to lessen those costs.

944.94.text:
We need to make it
  much easier for them

947.91.text:
when they go to college
  not to have such high debt.

950.95.text:
And then the interest rates
 almost become a nominal issue.

957.69.text:
- Student loan interest is
   an area that I looked at

960.39.text:
because knowing that the Ag
Commissioner sits on the bank--

962.83.text:
or the Industrial Commission
  which oversees the

964.43.text:
Bank of North Dakota, this was
 an area where we could lead.

967.40.text:
And in this campaign
   we've always tried to lead

969.64.text:
with ideas, this
  is a marketplace of
  ideas in a campaign,

974.54.text:
We advocate for one
   percent across the board.

977.01.text:
We've had strong profits in
  the Bank of North Dakota,

979.35.text:
strong profits from
their student loan part

981.91.text:
of that portfolio, and I want
 to set North Dakota apart

985.12.text:
because we have a huge
 workforce shortage

987.75.text:
in the state of North Dakota,
 short term and long term.

990.42.text:
When I graduated from
 NDSU 22 years ago,

995.19.text:
I was able to
  graduate with $7,000

997.26.text:
in student loan debt,
average is now $27,000.

1001.33.text:
We're not giving money away,
  they pay the money back.

1003.94.text:
North Dakota has a
 very low default rate.

1005.84.text:
But if they look at that
   one percent interest rate

1008.21.text:
across the board, flat, less
  than 5.29, this brings--

1012.01.text:
keeps our students here, it
 could bring other workers here

1015.18.text:
that can consolidate that
   loan, become the welders

1018.02.text:
and the electricians that
  we need in the energy sector

1020.82.text:
of North Dakota, become
  the engineers for tomorrow,

1023.92.text:
the agronomist and
 the animal scientists

1026.79.text:
that our agriculture
  needs, so I think

1028.69.text: it's really a matter of leading.

1030.63.text:
Obviously have to work
  with the Board of Higher Ed

1032.53.text:
to make sure that we control
  the cost of education

1034.97.text:
as best we can, advocate
to the legislature.

1038.20.text:
But what we could do
  as Ag Commissioner,

1040.34.text:
we'll start with the
  Bank of North Dakota

1042.01.text:
in reinvesting those profits
  in our next generation.

1044.71.text:
- I'm going to see if we can
  get three more topics in,

1046.65.text: so let's move on to another one.

1047.85.text:
Crop prices, once
 high, are now falling.

1050.45.text:
What are your views
  on crop prices?

1052.08.text:
How much input should
 the government have
 or should the free

1054.79.text:
market just kind of work
  its way through crop prices?

1057.89.text:
Ryan Taylor, you
start this time.

1059.93.text:
- [Ryan] Crop prices have
   plummeted in North Dakota.

1062.19.text:
And as I said, you know,
 those of us on the cattle side

1064.53.text:
have been enjoying
   good prices yet,

1066.40.text:
but we know this
changes in a heartbeat.

1068.70.text:
When we look at the size
  of crop and we know from an

1071.47.text:
Ag econ background that it's a
 supply and a demand function.

1075.54.text:
North Dakota I think is
  interesting in that not only

1077.48.text:
is it a supply and a demand
  function, it's also an issue

1080.41.text:
of rail transportation,
   and while the world market

1083.25.text:
is going to continue to work
  on where that price is set,

1086.42.text:
North Dakota farmers are,
   I think, what I hear them

1088.82.text:
in the campaign trail most is
 further frustrated by the fact

1092.59.text:
that they've got a dollar basis
that gives them less money

1094.79.text:
for their crop than many
  other places in this country

1097.53.text:
because of the bottleneck we
  have in rail transportation.

1100.63.text:
That's an area where I
   think the Ag Commissioner

1102.84.text:
needs to focus, we know markets
are going to ebb and flow.

1106.17.text:
We're lucky to have
  low interest rates.

1108.44.text:
But hopefully our farmers and
 ranchers have got their house

1111.88.text:
in order after some good
years in agriculture,

1115.41.text:
based on world demand, based
  on the fact that the market

1119.49.text:
is growing and more people
  are demanding our products.

1122.45.text:
But when we produce, we can
 see it go the other direction.

1126.16.text:
So we know that market
 prices are going to do

1128.49.text:
what they do based
 on supply and demand.

1131.20.text:
As Ag Commissioner, let's
  work on rail transportation.

1134.43.text:
Let's get part of that dollar
 basis back for our producers.

1137.27.text: And let's make sure we're ready

1138.47.text:
to capitalize on
   the next increase.

1143.74.text:
- My farm is experiencing the
 same difficulties that we are

1147.95.text:
seeing clear across the upper
 midwest and across the nation.

1151.45.text:
The markets swung too
 far one way, and now

1154.02.text:
they've swung too far
 back the other way.

1156.79.text:
I need above $4.10 a bushel
 just to break even on my corn.

1160.16.text:
And right now my
 local market is 2.07.

1162.79.text:
That's a long ways away
from breaking even.

1165.63.text:
We need markets, and as Ag
 Commissioner, I've stepped out

1169.64.text: and built some of those markets.

1171.54.text:
We've taken delegations
into other countries.

1174.14.text:
We're now exporting into 73
  countries around the world.

1179.01.text:
In my previous life I worked
  with international markets

1181.91.text:
and developed more of
 those relationships.

1183.68.text:
When we're out there,
 we're now working

1185.98.text:
in those different
   markets to develop

1187.75.text:
those relationships and
move our commodities.

1194.59.text:
If you include animal
  agriculture, we're up to 50

1198.30.text:
We have homes for
   them out there.

1199.87.text: We need to work on those issues.

1201.60.text:
The other issue about rail
   service, it's a concern.

1204.67.text:
Right now that basis
  is $1 to $1.15.

1208.41.text:
It's about 60 cents to 30
 cents over what it should be.

1213.25.text:
That's taking a lot of money
  out of the rural economy,

1215.71.text:
out of our farmers' pockets,
  it's one of the reasons

1218.08.text:
I worked with the Port of
   Vancouver and started that

1220.19.text:
over a year and a half
  ago, so that we can look at

1224.59.text:
They're bringing supplies
   and products and equipment

1226.66.text:
into North Dakota, we're using
 those cars to backhaul grain

1231.13.text:
in the Pacific Northwest and
  get them out of this area,

1234.23.text:
out of these markets and
into different markets

1236.77.text:
across the globe, and
   we'll continue to do that.

1239.24.text:
Our exports have increased
   by 70 percent in the last

1242.41.text:
four years, I'm committed
  to continue to look at those

1246.18.text:
exports and other markets
   because 96 percent

1248.38.text:
of our world's population
   is outside of our borders.

1252.75.text:
When you look at 80
  percent of our buying power

1254.95.text:
is outside of our borders and
 92 percent of the middle class

1258.22.text:
growth is going to exist
outside of our borders.

1260.69.text:
- We need to move
  on to another issue.

1262.13.text:
That's affordable housing,
   this question comes

1263.76.text:
from our co-sponsor AARP,
  continues to be a challenge

1267.13.text:
across North Dakota,
 especially in the west

1268.83.text:
where it's very
   high rent prices.

1270.77.text:
Many people including
  seniors have been displaced

1274.64.text:
As a member of the
 Industrial Commission,

1276.61.text: what would you do to accelerate

1278.08.text:
building of affordable housing,
Doug Goehring, you go first.

1284.92.text:
We need it for those that
   are on fixed incomes.

1287.25.text:
We have those that work
in the service industry

1289.22.text:
in western North
Dakota, but clear across

1290.79.text:
the whole entire
 state of North Dakota.

1293.33.text:
Our elderly on fixed
incomes, we need to have

1297.33.text:
We've been supporting those
projects everywhere that we can.

1300.90.text:
And we've been looking
at tax credits to do so.

1305.70.text:
We've got to continue to
  look at that, ramp that up,

1308.17.text:
expand that program,
   create those opportunities

1311.38.text:
so that we get more investors
 involved in building more

1315.31.text:
affordable housing
  and working with the

1317.78.text:
Housing Finance Agency to
 make sure that we can identify

1321.22.text:
more communities and
 more needs out there.

1324.99.text:
- The Housing Finance
  Agency is under the purview

1327.29.text:
of the Industrial Commission,
 and I was proud in this race

1331.73.text:
of the North Dakota Realtors
  Association, an endorsement

1334.57.text:
that had gone to my
 opponent in the past,

1337.14.text:
and I think that says
   something about this race,

1339.81.text:
that they want creativity,
   and they want action.

1342.54.text:
And they want someone
who will fight for those

1344.91.text:
tax credits, not just in an
 election year, but every year.

1348.41.text:
The housing incentive fund
 obviously needs more dollars.

1351.12.text:
We have a biennium
   for that fund,

1353.95.text: and it was gone in six months.

1355.82.text:
So I would be an Ag
Commissioner who would represent

1358.32.text:
the Industrial Commission, step
in front of the legislature

1360.43.text:
and say we need to fund this
  at a much more robust rate.

1363.13.text:
I would work with the
 Housing Finance Agency to get

1365.76.text:
more supply on the ground so
 that our residents don't feel

1368.57.text:
like they have to move out
   of their home communities.

1370.97.text:
Maybe expand that beyond
multi-family housing

1374.11.text:
to single family housing,
  and make sure that our rents

1378.51.text:
are affordable, that our
 elderly in particular can stay

1382.85.text:
in their homes, whether they
  live in Williston or Fargo.

1385.68.text:
We have housing pressures
   all across this state.

1388.19.text:
And we know that this office
 is much more than agriculture.

1391.92.text:
And we have a unique
opportunity to do more.

1394.26.text:
- We got a quick 30-- sir, do
 you want-- go ahead respond.

1396.43.text:
- [Doug] Yeah. - [Matt]
30 seconds then 30
for Ryan, go ahead.

1398.46.text:
- I think Mr. Taylor is being
 a bit naive or deceptive

1401.17.text:
because the reality is it
  was well over two years ago

1403.44.text: that we started the tax credits.

1404.87.text:
So we started working on
those, and we built them

1406.64.text:
into the program, so
  either you're naive

1413.25.text: - We know that the tax credits

1414.41.text:
were depleted in
   six months' time.

1417.02.text:
- [Matt] Doug, we got
   about 30 seconds left-- -
   [Doug] We worked on that.

1418.58.text:
-[Matt] Before closing if
   you want to keep talking.

1419.99.text:
- We have to continue to
work on, and that's what

1421.45.text:
we're doing, we came up with
  ways to address this issue,

1423.82.text:
to build affordable housing
 in our communities, and we're

1425.96.text:
going to continue to do that,
 and we're not going to stop.

1430.16.text:
then we'll move to
  closing statements.

1432.06.text:
- We know that the
 housing is important,

1433.77.text:
and we know it needs
  work every day.

1435.17.text:
We know that the legislature
  meets every two years

1437.00.text:
and that's where the
 funding stream comes.

1438.64.text:
- [Ryan] So we have work to do.
- [Matt] Okay.

1442.37.text:
- Closing statements, one
   minute closing statement.

1444.84.text: - We are the envy of the nation.

1446.81.text:
And I believe that we need
  to continue down that path.

1450.08.text:
We cannot go back to failed
and flawed policies of the past

1453.45.text:
where we had government trying
 to pick winners and losers.

1457.76.text:
We need to stay on track,
   we have a bright future.

1460.69.text:
We have two large industries
that can serve this state well.

1463.83.text:
They do serve us
 well, we work together

1465.93.text:
to make those things happen,
  agriculture is one of those

1469.90.text:
leading industries that we
  need to continue to focus on

1473.17.text:
because it's going to be
  here for a long, long time.

1476.31.text:
Diversity, innovation,
  research, and trade are some

1480.75.text:
of those basic
initiatives and elements

1482.98.text:
that will help us become
   and stay really efficient,

1486.59.text:
effective, and competitive
   in a global market.

1489.59.text:
- [Matt] Okay, Ryan
Taylor, final one minute

1493.16.text:
- [Ryan] We look forward to
  the finish of this campaign

1494.93.text:
and what's been a very
 competitive campaign

1497.60.text:
and one that we look
  forward to winning.

1499.97.text:
We know that North Dakota needs
leadership in agriculture.

1503.50.text:
North Dakota needs leadership
 on the Industrial Commission

1508.31.text:
We know that farms dictate
 the economy of all 53 counties

1512.78.text:
in this state, that we need to
 have an economy that's going

1515.01.text:
to be diverse enough to still
 pivot away once the energy

1517.82.text:
is gone, whether it's
30 or 40 years from now.

1521.12.text:
We need to have an Agriculture
 Department that is stable.

1524.16.text:
We need to have a commissioner
 who brings people together,

1527.49.text:
who steps up and leads and
   is creative and has ideas

1531.20.text:
and make sure that we don't
  have 70 percent turnover

1533.83.text:
in the department, that
  really works hard to forward

1536.84.text:
agriculture every day in North
 Dakota, and that we always

1539.54.text:
bring people together,
   whether it's Ag or energy

1542.27.text:
or conservation, we need
to articulate a vision

1545.61.text:
for this state that
everyone can get behind.

1547.75.text:
And we know that we
  can do that and that

1549.68.text:
North Dakota's tomorrow will
  be even brighter than today.

1552.72.text:
- I want to thank both of
   my guests for being here,

1554.65.text:
Ryan Taylor, Doug Goehring,
  good luck on election day.

1556.89.text: This has been the debate for

1560.46.text:
I'm Matt Olien,
  thanks for watching

1580.25.text:
- [Voiceover] Funding
 for Election 2014
 coverage is provided

1583.28.text:
in part by AARP, a non-profit,
 non-partisan association,

1588.09.text:
86,000 strong in North Dakota,
 AARP fights on real issues

1593.36.text:
that matter to you
   and your family.

1595.86.text:
And by the members
   of Prairie Public.
